title: 104_hr1114
content: AUTHORITY FOR 16- AND 17-YEAR-OLDS TO LOAD MATERIALS INTO SCRAP PAPER BALERS AND PAPER BOX COMPACTORS. Section 13(c) of the Fair Labor Standards Act is amended to allow 16- and 17-year-old employees to load materials into scrap paper balers and paper box compactors that meet safety standards. They are not permitted to operate or unload the machines while loading. The Fair Labor Standards Act allows 16- and 17-year-old employees to load materials into scrap paper balers and paper box compactors that meet safety standards. The machines must have an on-off switch with key-lock control held by employees 18 years or older, kept in the off position when not in use, and operated by employees' employer. The employer must provide notice that 16- and 17-year-old employees can only load scrap paper balers and paper box compactors meeting safety standards. Employees under 18 cannot operate or unload these machines. Employers must report any injuries to employees under 18 to the Secretary. The employer must report any injury or fatality of an employee under 18 resulting from contact with a scrap paper baler or paper box compactor during loading, operation, or unloading. The reports will be used by the Secretary to assess the safety impact of the regulations and must include employer details and incident location. Employers must report injuries or deaths of employees under 18 involving scrap paper balers or paper box compactors to the Secretary within 10 days. Reports should include details of the incident, employee, date, injury description, and equipment involved. The Secretary cannot solely rely on these reports to determine violations of child labor laws. The Secretary must investigate and inspect potential violations of child labor laws before making a determination. Reporting requirements will expire 2 years after enactment. SEC. 2. Civil money penalty amended for Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. Section 16(e) is updated to include section 13(c)(5). SEC. 3. Construction clarification for apprentices and student learners exemption.
